name: Reasoning with different units of length

skills.name: Measure and estimate the length and heights of objects in terms of other objects
Reasoning with different units of length (US)

explanations.A: If we count each of the paper clips that is right underneath the pencil, there are 6.
explanations.B: I think you started counting at the beginning of the row of paperclips, but we only want to count the ones right under the pencil.
explanations.C: Hmm, you have counted too many paperclips... Make sure you only count the ones right under the pencil.
explanations.D: That is all the paperclips, but which ones are right under the pencil showing its length?

explanations.A: I think you started counting at the beginning of the row of paperclips, but we only want to count the ones right under the pencil.
explanations.B: That is all the paperclips, but which ones are right under the pencil showing its length?
explanations.C: Hmm, you have counted too many paperclips... Make sure you only count the ones right under the pencil.
explanations.D: If we count each of the paper clips that is right underneath the pencil, there are 5.

explanations.A: The pencil starts at 2cm, but you need to find the difference between where it starts and where it ends.
explanations.B: That's the full length of the ruler, but we just want the length of the part from the start to the end of the pencil.
explanations.C: You found the end of the pencil correctly, but does it start at 0?
explanations.D: The pencil starts at 2cm on the ruler and ends at 15cm. 15 - 2 = 13, so the pencil is 13cm long.

explanations.A: You found the end of the pencil correctly, but does it start at 0?
explanations.B: The pencil starts at 4cm on the ruler and ends at 18cm. 18 - 4 = 14, so the pencil is 14cm long.
explanations.C: The pencil starts at 4cm, but you need to find the difference between where it starts and where it ends.
explanations.D: That's the full length of the ruler, but we just want the length of the part from the start to the end of the pencil.

explanations.A: Centimeters and inches are not the same. Is 1 inch less than 1cm, or more?
explanations.B: 1 inch is more than 1 cm, so will 8 inches be less than 8 cm?
explanations.C: 1 inch is more than 1 cm (it's about 2.5cm), so 8 inches is more than 8 cm.
explanations.D: Can you picture 1 inch? Is it bigger or smaller than 1cm? So will 8 inches be bigger or smaller than 8cm?

explanations.A: 1 cm is less than 1 inch (it's about 0.4 inches), so 16 cm is LESS than 16 inches.
explanations.B: 1 cm is less than 1 inch, so will 16cm be more than 16 inches?
explanations.C: Centimeters and inches are not the same. Is 1 cm less than 1 inch, or more?
explanations.D: Can you picture 1cm? Is it bigger or smaller than 1 inch? So will 16cm be bigger or smaller than 16 inches?

explanations.A: Yards and meters are very similar measurements, but they're not exactly the same. Do you remember if a yard is bigger or smaller than a meter?
explanations.B: 1 yard is less than 1m (it's about 0.9m) so 8 yards is less than 8m
explanations.C: 1 yd is less than 1m, so is 8 yd more than 8m?
explanations.D: Can you picture 1 yard? Is it bigger or smaller than 1m? So will 8 yards be bigger or smaller than 8m?

explanations.A: 1m is more than 1 yd, so is 10m less than 10 yd?
explanations.B: Yards and meters are very similar measurements, but they're not exactly the same. Do you remember if a meter is bigger or smaller than a yard?
explanations.C: 1 meter is more than 1 yard (it's about 1.1 yards) so 10 meters is more than 10 yards.
explanations.D: Can you picture 1 meter? Is it bigger or smaller than 1 yd? So will 10 m be bigger or smaller than 10 yards?

explanations.A: The cup is 12 cm tall, that's not the same as 12mm. Will it be more than 12mm, or less?
explanations.B: Is 1 cm less than 1mm? So is 12 cm less than 12mm?
explanations.C: Each cm is equal to 10mm, so 12cm will be 120mm. It takes more mm than cm to make the same length, because they are smaller.
explanations.D: Can you picture 1 cm? Is it bigger or smaller than 1 mm? So will 12 cm be bigger or smaller than 12 mm?

explanations.A: Is 1 mm less than 1cm? So is 140mm more than 140cm?
explanations.B: Every 10 mm is equal to 1 cm, so 140mm will be 14cm. It takes less cm than mm to make the same length, because they are bigger.
explanations.C: The cup is 140mm tall, that's not the same as 140cm. Will it be more than 140cm, or less?
explanations.D: Can you picture 1 mm? Is it bigger or smaller than 1 cm? So will 140mm be bigger or smaller than 140cm?
